_graphic.alt: image of timeline 2016 until 2020
_graphic.attribution: source: National Audit Office. Recent lessons show weaknesses across a number of modelling programmes. The solutions are relatively simple which you can see in section two (demonstrate)

_items.title: lesson of 2016
_items.body:
In the early to mid 2010’s the government used a ‘levy control framework’ to estimate and monitor forecast costs from three levied funded renewable energy schemes 

Lessons:

1) Having a governance structure is good. But for it to work it needs to be used

2) It is important to keeping a close eye on model assumptions, particularly those which have the potential to materially change the models output

3) Intelligence sharing on modelling assumptions could have been improved.

4) Senior officials focused too much on the models central forecast and not enough on the full range of plausible outcomes

_graphic.alt: image of wind farm

_pin.alt: image of the levy control framework, and its out of data assumptions leading to its closure

_items.title: lesson of 2018
_items.body:
In 2011, the Renewable Heat Incentive (RHI) was launched. This is a scheme designed to encourage a switch from fossil fuel heating systems to lower-carbon alternatives in homes and businesses.

Lessons:

1) Having a governance system is important to scrutinise model design, application and reporting of results.

2) Parent organisations need to have sufficient oversight of the activity being undertaken in its arm’s length bodies, particularly where these bodies are delivering on its behalf

3) Assumptions should be underpinned by an evidence base and subject to independent review.

4) The system focused too much on the central estimate and not on the full range of plausible outcomes.
_items.strapline: Low carbon heating of homes and businesses and the Renewable Heat Incentive, National Audit Office

_graphic.alt: image of house with boilers, heatpumps and biomass

_pin.alt: image of renewable heat incentive and estimates that were unreliable

_items.title: lesson of 2018
_items.body:
In 2012, the government set an obligation on energy suppliers to roll out smart meters in all homes and small businesses by 2019.

lessons:

1) Keeping models up to date help management keep an eye on progress and risks.

2) It is important to keep a close eye on model assumptions, particularly those which have the potential to materially change the models output

3) If assumptions are not kept up to date, knowledge drawn from models will also be out of date.
_items.strapline: more timely data would have helped monitoring of costs

_graphic.alt: image of a smart meter

_pin.alt: image of smart meter rollout, and over optimistic assumptions weakening the business case

_items.title: lesson of 2020
_items.body:
Carrier strike provides the ability for the UK to launch fixed-wing aircraft from a ship to undertake several military tasks (see diagram). The costs of running this capability are significant and the MoD use models to forecasts costs ten years ahead.

Lessons:

1) The classification of a model as business critical typically drives increased scrutiny of that model. Conversely, the lack of a business critical classification can lead to reduced scrutiny. This highlights the importance of these classifications.

2) For a governance structure to be effective, it needs a ‘complete’ view of forecast costs to support long-term planning

3) Optimism bias can imply greater certainty in a model’s output.

_graphic.alt: image of defence aircraft

_pin.alt: image of carrier strike programme, and incomplete assumptions of longer term costs

title: The 8 Macpherson recommendations for better modelling
displayTitle: The 8 Macpherson recommendations for better modelling

_items.title: 1: all business critical models should have quality assurance
_items.body:
not just the outputs, but input and methodology and assumptions too

the level of assurance depends on the model, but more is needed for business critical models

_items.title: 2: quality assurance is a specialism
_items.body:
business critical models should be managed by specialist modelling staff

but this also means allowing space for training and development of expertise

_items.title: 3: senior responsible owners
_items.body:
every business critical model should have a senior responsible owner (SRO)

it's more than just a tick box, SROs are accountable for ensuring model risks, assumptions and limitations are managed and understood by users.

_items.title: 4: publish a list of business critical models
_items.body:
the accounting officer for each department (or arms length body) should publish an up to date list of business critical models in its annual report

the report should also detail whether there is a QA framework in place too

_items.title: 5: build a QA culture
_items.body:
each department (or arms length body) should have a plan to create the right environment:

culture: leadership, internal challenge, personal objectives, promoting understanding across the organisation

capacity: building time for QA, drawing on external expertise

control: a clear governance framework

_items.title: 6: build effective QA processes
_items.body:
this includes guidance documents, but each department or ALB will need to consider

how it defines "business critical" and proportionate QA

how it documents QA (for example checklists)

how it manages handover of knowledge

_items.title: 7: create an expert cross departmental modelling group
_items.body:
this is part of sharing best practice

each department or arms length body should have a champion on this group

but in addition, everyone involved in modelling in each department should engage with their champion too

_items.title: 8: organisations should review progress against these recommendations
_items.body:
this was done 12 months when these recommendations were published in 2013

has your organisation reviewed progress since then?

_items.title: The BEIS QA tracker
_items.body:
•Central register of all known models in BEIS

•Holds basic information about models such as:

-Description of model

-Software and hosting platform

-Governance roles

-Business criticality

-Links to model, its documentation and its QA log

_graphic.alt: image of analysis and charts

_items.title: Scoring QA
_items.body:
The tool

•keeps a record of all model’s current and previous QA scores

•produces monthly summary statistics looking at overall state of model QA.

•as of 2020, the spreadsheets is tracking around 95 BEIS models, 80 of which are in use.

_graphic.alt: image of donut chart of average score for business critical models

_items.title: Keep records up to date
_items.body:
There are 3 main types of updates:

•Monthly. If no QA log has been produced or they haven’t provided model information.

•Quarterly. If a QA log has been produced, but the score has not reached the threshold (85% for non-business critical, 90% for business critical) BEIS ask for quarterly updates

•Yearly. If the model has achieved the required QA score, BEIS send yearly e-mails asking if the information is still up-to-date

_graphic.alt: image of timeseries of improvement of average score for models over time

_items.title: Scope
_items.body:
The Modelling Integrity Team run “QA colleges” roughly every 6 weeks for all newcomers to the department.

They introduce QA templates in BEIS and how to use them.

They also introduce themselves and emphasise that all new models are included on the Tracking Spreadsheet.

Despite this, the truth is there are probably models in the department that we don’t know about. We are therefore introducing a yearly schedule whereby we e-mail all analysts in the department asking if any models are missing from the Tracking Spreadsheet.

_graphic.alt: imagine of number of models tracked and scored over time

title: Macpherson recommendation 1
body: What is a model? examples from across government

_items.title: What is a model
_items.body:
most people agree a model is a simplified representation of reality

models have many purposes, which is not exhaustive as a list

any suggested QA processes should not duplicate existing QA. However, if in doubt, we advise doing the QA due diligence

_graphic.alt: Image of a table defining models by their purpose First, Policy simulation is about Appraisal of policy options, analysis of impact on people, finances, etc  Example is the Intra Government Tax Benefit Model   Second, Forecasting is about Assessing the future,  perhaps to provide base information for policy development or financial planning for example the State Pension expenditure forecast   Three, Financial evaluation is about Assessment of liability or future cost, for example Pension liabilities, higher education loan repayment model   Procurement and commercial Evaluation is about VfM or affordability and award of contracts for example Awarding of rail franchises   Planning  is about planning current actions based on future forecasts, for example Teachers, NHS   Science-based is Understanding and forecasting natural systems, for example Climate change   Allocation is Distribution of funding across organisations responsible for service delivery, for example the Police allocation formula

_items.title: What is a business critical model?
_items.body:
This is a judgment of the impacts on business risk and complexity

for example, many departments use a rule of thumb that business critical risks are

DEL spend above £1m

AME spend above £50m

High reputational consequences 

likewise, model complexity is a judgement of process risk. 

We advise, if in doubt, always err on the side of due diligence

_graphic.alt: image of indicative types of QA that might be expected given different levels of risk  Low business risk and simple modelling needs minimal proportionate QA such as testing and versioning Higher risk and complex modelling needs internal, external auditing in addition

_items.title: Not sure if it's a model or not?
_items.body: if in doubt...do the QA due diligence

_graphic.alt: image of not sure if quality is really good or testing was really lousy

_items.title: Model design
_items.body: assess model risk: key questions

_graphic.alt: image of risk assessment questions: With reference to the impact on Ofwat and/or the water industry, how material in financial terms is the spreadsheet? In terms of reputational impact on Ofwat, how significant is the spreadsheet? How significant to Ofwat are the legal issues related to the spreadsheet? Who will be relying on the results of the spreadsheet for decision making or other purposes? What are the sources of inputs / assumptions for the model? How many individuals are involved in the development and use of model and its outputs How flexible is model? How complex is the model structure Number of unique formulae (ignoring inputs and labels) Is the model compliant with the FAST standard? How novel is the modelling approach? How much resource has been allocated to the modelling exercise?

_items.title: formula reviewing
_items.body: what, when and when else to review formulas

_graphic.alt: High-risk projects or when high levels of assurance are required Detailed analysis of all formulas in a model to ensure they are performing the desired function Checking consistency within a model where calculation sheets are duplicated

_items.title: Parallel build
_items.body:
•Requires full engagement by the reviewer with the purpose and functioning of the model, and therefore considers both validation and verification of outputs

•Parallel build may not identify deficiencies in coding or inefficient coding if it provides the same result as the parallel build. 

•As the parallel build uses the same inputs it is unlikely to identify errors in the input assumptions themselves

_graphic.alt: • What is a parallel build review? 	• When a reviewer independently builds a calculation block and reviews whether their outputs match the original model • When should you do it? 	• High-risk projects or when high levels of assurance are required When formulas or calculation blocks are convoluted and hard to understand

title: further information
body:
you can find more detail in the AQUA book part A. This section is written for policy makers

Chapter 2 explains how commissioning analysis relates to the problem under investigation and the decision the analysis is helping to inform.

Chapter 3 provides an overview of how to commission analysis that will be fit-for-purpose.

Chapter 4 introduces the two main questions to be asked of any piece of analysis: is it the right analysis and has it been conducted correctly.

Chapter 5 explains that uncertainty is inherent in all analysis and needs to be acknowledged, understood, managed and clearly communicated.
